question: Question_B_06_(b)
statement:
Consider the linear systems described below. In cases (a)-(d), write a
\emph{single}, possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix
of the system.

Two equations in three unknowns with solutions

\begin{align*}\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
0
\end{bmatrix}+
t
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

where t is a parameter.
sols:
We have 2 equations in 3 unknowns so the original matrix is
$2\times{3}$. Such a system always has infinitely many solutions and
hence at least one free variable. Denote the components of the solution
vector \textbf{x} as $x_1$, $x_2$, and $x_3$. The solution we are given
suggests \emph{x\textsubscript{3} = t} as the free variable. Further

\begin{align*}
x_1&=1+t\\
x_2&=2\\
x_3&=t\end{align*}

Therefore $x_1=1+x_3$ or $x_1-x_3=1$. This means we can write our
augmented matrix as

\begin{align*}\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1  &  0  &  -1  &  1\\
0  &  1  &  0  &  2
\end{array}\right]\end{align*}
hints:
Two equations and three unknowns, what does that mean for the size of
the matrix we are looking for?
